Photocatalytic synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) has emerged as a promising approach because of its simplicity and environmental benefits. However, significant challenges remain obstacles to their advancement, such as the rapid recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and sluggish surface redox reactions on nonmetallic organic catalysts. Metal-based organic catalysts with tunable electronic structures are considered ideal for exploring the mechanisms and structure-performance relationships in H2O2 synthesis. This review summarizes the fundamental principles of photocatalytic H2O2 synthesis via oxygen reduction and water oxidation reactions. Recent advancements in electronic structure tuning strategies for metal-based organic catalysts are critically examined, focusing on their impact on light absorption range, photogenerated carrier separation, O2 activation, and the selective generation of H2O2. In addition, this review comprehensively evaluates the applications of sacrificial agents in photocatalytic reaction systems and offers insights into the future development of metal-based organic catalysts for H2O2 photosynthesis. Graphical Abstract This review systematically explores the effects of modulating the electronic structure of metal-based organic catalysts on light harvesting, photogenerated charge carrier separation, oxygen reduction processes, and selectivity in H2O2 generation. In addition, the roles and limitations of sacrificial agents are discussed, and guidance is provided for rational catalyst design. Keywords Metal based organic catalysts Electronic structure Photocatalytic H2O2 synthesis Oxygen reduction reaction Water oxidation reaction S-scheme photocatalysis 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a globally significant chemical, has garnered extensive attention for its pivotal roles in healthcare, the electronics industry, chemical synthesis, and other fields [1–4]. Currently, over 95% of global H2O2 production relies on the anthraquinone (AQ) autoxidation process [5]. However, this method requires large-scale processing facilities, involves complex operations, and poses serious pollution problems, thereby limiting its sustainable development. Photocatalysis stands out as the most promising approach for H2O2 production, requiring merely light as an energy source and utilizing H2O and O2 as materials for redox reactions catalyzed by semiconductor photocatalysts [6–8]. This method leverages the inexhaustible nature of light energy, features a straightforward process, and generates non-polluting by-products. Various semiconductor and composite catalysts based on metal oxides (TiO2, WO3, ZnO, BiVO4, etc.) [9–14] and metal sulfides (In2S3, CdS, MoS2, etc.) have been proposed [15–20]. Despite these advancements, the presence of highly charged compounds in inorganic semiconductor materials limits the efficiency of H2O2 production. In 1985, Yanagida et al. [21] reported that poly(p-phenylene) photoreduced H2O to H2 in the presence of electron donors. Since then, organic semiconductor photocatalysts such as carbon nitride (CN) [22–27], covalent triazine frameworks (CTF) [28–31], covalent organic frameworks (COF) [32–37], conjugated microporous polymers (CMP) [38–40], and metal-organic frameworks (MOF) have been discovered [41–44]. The photocatalytic performance of these organic photocatalysts can be readily modulated by altering their building blocks, indicating their significant potential for practical applications [45]. Researchers have strategically optimized light harvesting [46], carrier separation kinetics [47,48], band structure, active sites, and reaction processes to improve photocatalytic efficiency [49,50]. However, the complex molecular structures of organic semiconductor photocatalysts often hinder a clear understanding of their structural evolution and catalytic enhancement mechanisms. Among organic semiconductors, metal-based organic photocatalysts offer several advantages: (1) metal sites act as electron sinks to inhibit the recombination of photogenerated carriers, (2) metal atoms connect with neighboring atoms to form electron-transfer bridges, (3) metal doping introduces intermediate energy levels and provides electron traps, (4) metal sites serve as activation sites for O2, (5) the microenvironment in the vicinity of the metal can be adjusted, and (6) single-atom catalysts provide well-defined O2 adsorption modes. Zhuang et al. [51] developed a metal-coordinated polymer, Cd3(C3N3S3)2, that effectively reduced O2 under visible light, achieving remarkable photocatalytic H2O2 production at millimolar levels. This pioneering work provides new insights into metal-polymer catalysts for photosynthetic H2O2 production. Since then, metal-based organic catalysts for H2O2 photocatalytic synthesis have been extensively developed [52–58], including metal-organic frameworks, metal-modified covalent frameworks, metal single-atom catalysts, and metal-modified carbon nitrides. Metal-based organic catalysts with tunable electronic structures offer innovative solutions to address the limitations of narrow light-absorption ranges, low carrier-separation efficiencies, and insufficient catalytic activity and selectivity [59]. Metal-based organic catalysts in the production of H2O2 has developed in recent years. To advance in this field, it is essential to review the latest advances. Li et al. [60] provided an in-depth discussion on the advantages of metal single-atom catalysts (SACs) for H2O2 production. Qiu et al. [53] summarized overall progress in photocatalytic H2O2 production using MOF-based catalysts and discussed various MOF modification strategies. Zou et al. [61] detailed the mechanisms and factors influencing H2O2 production via MOF photocatalysis, revealing the limitations of MOFs and their modification requirements. Additionally, they outlined applications in in-situ pollutant degradation. Ding et al. [62] outlined the prospects and challenges of using metal-organic compounds for large-scale industrial H2O2 synthesis. To the best of our knowledge, relatively few comprehensive reviews have focused on electronic structure modulation of metal-based organic catalysts for photocatalytic H2O2 production. Therefore, to promote further research on metal-based organic materials for this application, this study summarizes recent progress in catalytic mechanisms, light harvesting and carrier behavior, energy band and electron structure tuning, and active site modification, as illustrated in Fig. 1 . Moreover, it highlights the impact of sacrificial agents on photocatalytic processes and provides insights and suggestions for future studies on innovative and efficient photocatalysts for H2O2 production. 2 Photocatalytic mechanisms 2.1 Fundamentals of H2O2 photosynthesis Photocatalytic H2O2 production generally involves five key steps: (1) absorption of photon energy by the semiconductor to trigger electron transitions (where E hv ≥ E g), (2) adsorption of O2 on the catalyst surface, (3) migration of photogenerated carriers, (4) surface reduction reactions, and (5) desorption of H2O2 from the catalyst surface, as illustrated in Fig. 2 [63–67]. The 2e– oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) pathway includes a one-step two-electron pathway and a two-step one–electron pathway. The two-step one-electron pathway, with only one electron in each step, is more favorable in terms of reaction kinetics. However, owing to the high reactivity of •O2 –, the two-step 2e– ORR pathway is less efficient for H2O2 production [68]. Thermodynamically, the one-step two-electron pathway (+0.68 V vs. VRHE) is significantly more favorable than the two-step one-electron pathway (–0.33 V vs. VRHE) [69]. Additionally, ground-state triplet oxygen (3O2) can be nonspontaneously transformed into singlet oxygen (1O2) in the excited state. As a long-lived electrophilic energy-transfer product, 1O2 can facilitate H2O2 production via a one-step two-electron pathway that is both kinetically and thermodynamically favorable [70]. The 4e– ORR pathway is also a competitive route. As shown in Fig. 2, the intermediate •OOH is common to both the 4e– and 2e– ORR pathways. The key to determining these two routes is the stability of the O–O bond and sufficient protonation [71]. Specifically, if the O–O bond in •OOH breaks to produce •O and •OH, or if timely protonation fails converting •OOH to H2O2, the reaction ultimately leads to H2O production. Theoretically, in addition to the 2e– ORR pathway, H2O2 can also be produced by the photogenerated hole-mediated water oxidation reaction (WOR). The WOR can proceed through either a one-or two-step 2e– WOR pathway or a 4e– WOR pathway. However, H2O2 production via WOR usually requires an excessively high oxidation potential (1.76 V vs. VRHE), which inevitably results in H2O2 decomposition. The direct WOR pathway is thermodynamically more favorable, whereas the indirect WOR pathway is kinetically more viable. Selective recombination of two •OH intermediates can produce H2O2, but further decomposition of •OH into •O results in the formation of H2O. These observations highlight the importance of stabilizing the •OOH intermediate and ensuring sufficient proton availability to favor H2O2 production over complete reduction to H2O (Fig. 2). 2.2 Light harvest and carrier separation Tailoring the electronic structure is a critical strategy for enhancing photocatalytic efficiency for metal-based organic catalysts, typically evaluated through parameters such as bandgap engineering, charge carrier dynamics, and metal-ligand orbital hybridization [72–74]. A superior photocatalyst should exhibit a bandgap suitable for visible light absorption to ensure efficient utilization of solar energy, while simultaneously facilitating the rapid migration of electrons and holes to active sites or surfaces, coupled with prolonged carrier lifetimes [75–78]. However, most photocatalysts are limited to ultraviolet (UV) light responsiveness, which constitutes only approximately 5% of the solar spectrum, thereby restricting their solar energy-harvesting capabilities. The weak screening effect and dielectric properties of organic conjugated structures lead to strong Coulombic force between photoelectrons and holes, producing large exciton binding energy. This severely hampers the separation and migration of photogenerated charges, becoming a crucial factor affecting photocatalytic activity [79]. Metal catalysts exhibit minimal bandgap characteristics and can be activated by visible or near-infrared radiation (NIR) to address the problem of light absorption [80]. When incorporated into organic frameworks as co-catalysts, metal ions or clusters function as efficient electron sinks, facilitating spatial and energetic separation of photogenerated electrons and holes. This is critical for mitigating charge recombination and enhancing photocatalytic efficiency [81]. In addition, metal atoms can bind with adjacent atoms to form electron transfer bridges, further improving electron-hole separation efficiency. Noble metal nanoparticles, including Au, Pd, Pt, and Ag, are highly effective co-catalysts owing to their stability and electron-withdrawing properties [82–84]. Zhang et al. [85] immobilized Au nanoparticles onto a hollow spherical COF (Au/TB-COF), as shown in Fig. 3(a) , thereby improving the light-harvesting capabilities of the COF and favoring the transfer and separation of photogenerated carriers. In-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis revealed a downshift in the Au 4f 7/2 and Au 4f 5/2 binding energies for AT-1 (with a nominal Au loading of 1 wt% on TB-COF), indicating an increase in electron density within the Au nanoparticles [86]. Conversely, an upshift in the N 1s peak suggested electron transfer from the TB-COF to the Au nanoparticles, which was further amplified under light irradiation (Figs. 3(b) and (c)). AT-1 exhibited the smallest electrochemical impedance (EIS) and highest photocurrent density, confirming that efficient electron transfer from TB-COF to Au promoted charge separation (Figs. 3(d) and (e)). In another study, Zhang et al. [87] synthesized a C3N4-based catalyst co-modified with single Pt atoms and 3,4,9,10–perylenetetracarboxylic acid diimide (PDI) (Pt/CP). In this system, single Pt atoms act as electron-rich sites that effectively suppress charge recombination (Fig. 3(f)). In-situ XPS revealed the accumulation of photogenerated electrons at the Pt sites, which enhanced the O2 reduction capability (Fig. 3(g)). Co nanoparticles have been shown to modulate the Fermi energy level and act as electron traps, thereby improving electron transport dynamics [88]. Ning et al. [89] synthesized a hybrid photocatalyst composed of Co-embedded nitrogen-doped carbon frameworks (Co-N-C) coupled with supramolecular perylene diimide (SA-PDI). Specifically, Co nanoparticles were embedded in the carbon framework via pyrolysis and thermal reduction, and Co-N-C/SA-PDI was obtained through in-situ self-assembly (Fig. 3(h)). Owing to multiple reflections and scattering of incident light within the 3D nanoporous carbonaceous framework of Co-N-C, Co-N-C/PDI exhibited a broader light absorption range (Fig. 3(i)). The enhanced interfacial charge separation efficiency was attributed to π–π interactions between SA and PDI and Co-N-C, coupled with Co nanoparticles serving as electron traps (Fig. 3(j)). XPS demonstrated that C=O, C–O–C, and adsorbed H2O peaks in Co-N-C/SA-PDI-70% shifted toward lower binding energies, suggesting enhanced surface electron density (Fig. 3(k)). Additionally, changes in the electron spin density and charge distribution of the nitrogen-doped carbon framework influenced adjacent carbon atoms and created surface-activation regions. This structural modification facilitated efficient electron transfer from SA-PDI to the nitrogen-rich carbon substrate of Co-N-C [90]. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is a cost-effective organic semiconductor with visible-light responsiveness and a tunable bandgap structure, making it a widely used platform in photocatalytic applications [91–93]. Its two-dimensional architecture, composed of periodic heptazine units, allows for precise atomic-level modification via doping strategies. Such modifications enable fine-tuning of its electronic structure and bandgap, thereby expanding its light absorption range and enhancing charge carrier separation efficiency [94,95]. Meanwhile, single-atom catalysts provide dispersed metal sites and high electrical conductivity, which is conducive to charge migration [96,97]. Recently, the integration of metal single-atom photocatalysts with g-C3N4 has garnered significant attention. Li et al. [98] developed a composite material featuring a single Cu atom anchored on N-doped graphene/carbon nitride nanosheets (Cu-NG/CN), which significantly enhanced charge separation efficiency, as illustrated in Fig. 4(a) . The single-atom Cu sites, coordinated by unsaturated N atoms, act as electron sinks to capture and store electrons in the excited state, thereby effectively suppressing electron-hole recombination (Fig. 4(b)) [99,100]. NG exhibited excellent electrical conductivity, and the covalent bonding between Cu, NG and, CN layers altered the bandgap of Cu-NG/CN. UV-vis DRS and transient photocurrent measurements demonstrated that Cu-NG/CN displayed enhanced light absorption and improved separation and migration efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers (Figs. 4(c) and (d)). Zheng [101] synthesized a series of K and I co-doped graphitic carbon nitrides (CN-KI-X, where X represents the mass of added KI) to modulate the electronic structure and enhance photocatalytic activity. Iodine atoms distributed at the material edges contributed to the formation of cyano groups as nitrogendefects, which narrowed the band gap, negatively shifted the conduction band (CB), and effectively improved photogenerated carrier generation (Fig. 4(e)). K atoms form chemical bonds with adjacent N atoms, optimizing the electronic structure of the system and promoting charge separation (Figs. 4(f) and (g)). N-KI-10 exhibited a higher generation rate constant and a lower decomposition rate constant, indicating higher H2O2 yield. (Fig. 4(h)). In another study, Hu [102] investigated alkali metal cation–adsorbed graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4). Positively charged alkali metal ions generate a local electric field on the catalyst surface, significantly prolonging carrier lifetimes (Figs. 4(i) and (j)). g-C3N4 absorbs photon energy to generate photogenerated charges, where electrons migrate towards the surface under the influence of K+-induced electric field, whereas holes remain within the organic bulk material (Fig. 4(k)). This electric field enhances charge separation efficiency, thereby improving the photocatalytic performance of the material. Transition metals (TMs), including Mn, Fe, Cu, Co, and Ni, possess tunable d orbitals, making them ideal candidates for constructing high-activity electrocatalysts [103]. However, these metals are prone to charge recombination, which limits their overall efficiency [104]. In contrast, main-group metals with a d 10 electronic configuration exhibit strong band-edge dispersion at the conduction band minimum, facilitating rapid migration of photogenerated electrons and enhancing photocatalytic performance [105]. Teng et al. [106] prepared a series of models where a single metallic ion was coordinated to a non-defective PCN unit (Melem_3M). Computational studies on approximate binding energies (Eabx) revealed that incorporating Sn4+ and In3+ into g-C3N4 effectively suppresses charge recombination, whereas the introduction of TMs tends to promote it (Fig. 5(a) ). The iso-surface of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) indicates that photogenerated electrons are highly localized at the In and Sn sites and facilitate the ORR (Fig. 5(b)). Furthermore, the lowest–energy transitions in Melem_3In3+ and Melem_3Sn4+ models are primarily charge-transfer excitations rather than localized transitions (Fig. 5(c)). This mechanism significantly enhances efficiency of the photocatalytic ORR for H2O2 production. Defect engineering has emerged as a powerful strategy for tailoring the chemical properties and electronic structures of catalysts to enhance their photocatalytic performance [107,108]. Recent studies have demonstrated that the introduction of defects into metal-based organic structures significantly enhances multiple processes, including O2 adsorption, photon harvesting, charge separation, and migration. For instance, Zhang et al. [49] introduced –C≡N groups and N vacancies into g-C3N4 for photocatalytic H2O2 generation. Advanced characterization revealed that these dual-defect sites resulted in more localized electron distribution. The n-π* transition of lone pair electrons at the defect site generates a new absorption band, thereby significantly boosting light absorption and carrier separation efficiency. Similarly, Hou et al. [109] designed surface defect sites (N vacancies) on CN and loaded CoO x nanoclusters to synthesize CoO x -N v CN. The N vacancies optimized the photoresponsive properties of CN, whereas the CoO x nanoclusters served as active sites for the ORR. Their synergistic effect altered the electronic structure, facilitated charge carrier separation, and enhanced ORR activity. Additionally, the lower K d value of CoO x -N v CN indicated that the synergy between N vacancies and CoO x nanoclusters suppressed H2O2 decomposition. Shen et al. [110] synthesized NTU-9 with missing linker-cluster domain (MLCD) defects through thermal decomposition (Fig. 5(d)). These defects introduced deep energy levels within the band gap, which served as electron-hole recombination centers (Figs. 5(e) and (f)) [111]. This structural modification not only affected charge recombination dynamics but also led to notable changes in electronic spin configuration. Specifically, a downward spin peak emerged near the Fermi energy level, attributed to spin polarization of electrons under light irradiation and the subsequent increase in spin-down electrons [112]. These spin-down electrons can only pair with oriented spin-up electrons, thereby increasing interfacial orbital-limited resistance, which is detrimental to the photocatalytic ORR (Fig. 5(g)). Yamashita et al. [113] conducted an in-depth investigation of defect engineering to enhance photocatalytic production of H2O2 using UiO-66-NH2 (Hf-UiO-66-NH2) as a model system. When missing-linker defects with acetate ligands were introduced (Figs. 5(h) and (i)), the Hf species in the clusters transitioned to electron-deficient states. This modification strengthened coordination bonds with organic linkers and enhanced the structural rigidity of Hf-UiO-66-NH2. The enhanced rigidity effectively dampened vibrational modes of the organic linkers, inhibiting non-radiative relaxation and ultimately enhancing photocatalytic efficiency. Additionally, the decomposition of H2O2 was prevented by weakening the interaction between H2O2 and Hf-oxo clusters. Single-component catalysts face challenges in balancing their redox capabilities and light-absorption ranges. The S-scheme heterostructure proposed by Yu offers a pivotal strategy to address this issue. An S-scheme heterojunction is formed by combining two semiconductors with staggered band structures. Because the Fermi level of the reduction photocatalyst (RP) is higher than that of the oxidation photocatalyst (OP), free electrons spontaneously transfer from RP to OP upon contact until their Fermi levels align (Fig. 6(a) ) [69]. Consequently, an internal electric field (IEF), directed from the RP to the OP, is generated, which drives electrons in the CB of the OP to migrate to the valence band (VB) of the RP and recombine with holes. Meanwhile, electrons in the CB of the RP and the holes in the VB of the OP migrate to the catalyst surface to undergo redox reactions. The successful construction of S-scheme heterojunctions broadened the light absorption range and enhanced the separation efficiency of the photogenerated charge carriers, thereby synergistically improving photocatalytic production efficiency of H2O2 from both kinetic and thermodynamic perspectives. Organic compounds exhibit structural tunability, and their abundant N and O atoms facilitate metal coordination, thereby promoting heterostructure formation. Qiu et al. [73] grew In2S3 in situ on COF to design a COF/In2S3 heterojunction (COFIS), which extended the light absorption range into the near–infrared region (Figs. 6(b) and (c)). In the absence of sacrificial agents, the H2O2 production rate reached an impressive 5713.20 μmol g–1 h–1. Meng et al. [114] constructed an S-scheme heterojunction by in situ growth of COF on ZnO to prepare ZnO/COF (ZCOF-x, where x represents the mass ratio of COF to ZnO). Fourier-transformed k 2-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) fitting curves revealed the presence of trace Zn–N bonds in ZCOF (Fig. 6(d)). In-situ XPS analysis demonstrated that electrons transferred from ZnO to the COF through Zn–N bonds under light irradiation (Figs. 6(e) and (f)). Femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopy (fs-TAS) results further confirmed interfacial charge transfer within the S-scheme heterojunction (Fig. 6(g)). Wang synthesized C3N4/NiIn2S4 composites via a solvothermal method, which exhibited dual functionality for simultaneous water evaporation and ORR catalysis under illumination (Fig. 6(h)) [115]. 3 Catalytic process 3.1 Adsorption and activation of O2 Understanding the participation of active sites in O2 adsorption and activation at the atomic scale is a prerequisite for improving ORR activity [116]. Metal SACs have garnered significant attention for ORR applications owing to their unique geometric configurations, adjustable electronic properties, and maximum atomic utilization efficiencies [117–122]. These catalysts can effectively serve as active sites for O2 adsorption and activation [123–126]. However, isolated metal atoms tend to aggregate into clusters [127–129]. To address this limitation, the development of suitable substrates with strong anchoring capabilities is essential for stabilizing single metal atoms [130–136]. The catalytic performance of SACs primarily depends on the microenvironment surrounding a single metal site [137]. SACs are typically characterized by symmetric coordination, forming M–N x catalytic sites. Recent studies have reported the synthesis of nickel single-atom catalysts supported on porous ultrathin graphitic carbon nitride (Ni-SAS/PuCN) with high Ni loading, achieved through a sequential process involving thermal stripping, ultrasonic exfoliation, and wet chemical precipitation [138] (Fig. 7(a) ). In-situ X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy revealed that the Ni-N3 site was dynamically transformed into an O1-Ni-N2 site upon O2 adsorption, which further formed •OOH intermediates and ultimately HOO-Ni-N2 (Fig. 7(b)). The structural evolution of the active site reduced the barrier for •OOH formation, thereby increasing H2O2 formation activity (Fig. 7(c)). Zhuang et al. [139] designed Li-C3N4 with dynamic metal–active centers. Under light irradiation, Li metal atoms can either migrate in the monolayer C3N4 or diffuse between C3N4 multilayers, resulting in a variation in the local coordination environment of Li (Fig. 7(d)). This atomic mobility dynamically modulated the local coordination environment of Li, facilitating H2O2 generation and enhancing the catalytic efficiency of the two-step single-electron ORR pathway (Fig. 7(e)). •O2 + •H → •OOH and •O2 → •O2 + •H are the rate-determining steps in the absence and presence of an applied electric field, respectively (Fig. 7(f)). This indicates that charge variation near the Li sites is crucial in determining the photocatalytic activity of Li-C3N4. Co-based catalysts effectively inhibit metal site shedding and radical attacks, rendering them highly promising candidates for efficient H2O2 production [140]. Based on different N coordination configurations, pyridine-type Co-N4 is an ideal candidate for the 4e– ORR, whereas pyrrole-type Co-N4 is more suitable for the 2e– ORR process [141–146]. Furthermore, studying the coexistence of the two N-coordination structures is important for understanding their combined effect on ORR activity and selectivity, and for systematically evaluating differences in the catalytic activity of M-N4 SAC families. Single-element fixation of the metal center (M-N4 coordination) restricts changes in its electronic structure. Furthermore, the symmetric arrangement of highly electronegative nitrogen atoms in the M–N4 configuration creates strong binding interactions with intermediates, thus limiting enhancements in catalytic activity [147–150]. In electrocatalytic oxygen reduction, significant efforts have been made to manipulate the electronic structure of single–atom metal centers using various strategies such as heteroatom doping (B, S, P), asymmetrical planar coordination (M–N x Y4–x , Y = S, P, etc.), and axial guest group effects (hydroxyl, pyridine, etc.) [151–153]. Currently, asymmetric planar coordination is the primary strategy for changing metal-centric environments in the field of photocatalysis. The charge and spin density of the metal center directly influence the adsorption capability of O2 and key oxygen intermediates, such as •OOH, thereby affecting ORR activity [154,155]. The electronic structure of metal atoms in SACs is modulated by their coordination environment, enabling optimized adsorption of •OOH intermediates while suppressing O–O bond cleavage, thereby facilitating the selective 2e– ORR pathway [156]. In particular, an asymmetric coordination microenvironment incorporating heteroatoms such as O, N, and S induces disparities in atomic radius and electronegativity among these heteroatoms. These disparities induce localized electronic structure modulation and geometrical configuration modification of the metal centers, collectively optimizing the electron distribution at the catalytically active sites. This optimization enhances the adsorption and dissociation kinetics of reactive intermediates [157–159]. This strategy is highly effective for unlocking the catalytic potential of SACs [160,161]. Miao et al. [162] synthesized a conjugated heptazine-amide-anthraquinone (AQ) polymer with a N3-Sb-O coordination structure (HAAQ–Sb) by introducing AQ and heptazine via an explosive crystallization method (Fig. 8(a) ). It significantly enhances O2 adsorption and effectively initiates H2O2 photosynthesis mediated by low-barrier hydrogen transfer. The apparent quantum yield (AQY) at 400 nm was 20.20%, and the SCC was 0.72%, both ranking among the highest values reported for C3N4 photocatalysts. Li et al. [149] synthesized a CN/Zn-OAc carbon nitride material with an asymmetric Zn-N3O moiety via a zinc acetate-anion-directed strategy (Fig. 8(b)). The different partial densities of states (PDOS) of the Zn orbitals demonstrate strong electronic coupling between Zn and O atoms, thus regulating the central electronic structure of Zn (Fig. 8(c)). Bader charge analysis and charge density differences indicate that Zn-N3O is more conducive to electron accumulation (Fig. 8(d)), thereby promoting ORR activity. The Gibbs free energy of the reaction pathway also confirms that Zn-N3O more likely adsorbs O2, activates it to generate •OOH, and then converts it to H2O2 (Fig. 8(e)). The Zn-N3O active site provides an optimal electronic environment for promoting the 2e– ORR pathway. Liu et al. [163] designed an oxygen-and potassium-dual-heteroatom-incorporated polymeric carbon nitride (O/K CN) with a rod–like structure (Fig. 8(f)). The dual-heteroatom incorporation and distinctive morphology synergistically increased the surface area while creating abundant active sites for O2 activation. The activation mechanism of O2 involves direct migration of electron from β spin-orbitals to π* orbitals (Figs. 8(g) and (h)). Notably, transitions are generally considered allowed only when the oscillator strengths (f) exceed 0.01. O/K-CN exhibits more permitted transition states, and its β-LUMO shows a higher orbital contribution to the excited state (Figs. 8(i) and (j)), thereby accelerating the activation of oxygen molecules. In addition, O/K-CN is more conducive to O2 adsorption and intermediate •OOH intermediate formation than the other catalysts, thus reducing the energy barrier for H2O2 formation (Fig. 8(k)). 3.2 Inhibition of hydrogen peroxide decomposition H2O2 production via photocatalytic ORR is a dynamic process between formation and decomposition, and the detected amount of H2O2 represents the net yield resulting from the competition between its generation and subsequent decomposition [164,165]. Under light irradiation, high temperatures, and alkaline environments, H2O2 readily decomposes into H2O, O2, OH–, HO2 •, or •OH. The decomposition of H2O2 occurs primarily via the following pathways: (1) redox reactions mediated by h+ or e–, (2) metal-induced Fenton-like reactions, and (3) radical chain reactions involving •O2 – and H2O2. The decomposition of H2O2 can be suppressed by maintaining a weakly acidic environment, operating at low temperatures, and using visible-light irradiation. Additionally, employing a two-phase system (water-benzyl alcohol) or a flow production system enables the timely separation of the generated H2O2, thereby preventing its decomposition on the catalyst surface. An ideal catalyst should not only improve catalytic activity of the ORR but also reduce the interaction with H2O2. Designing a hydrophobic catalyst surface can reduce the residence time of H2O2, thereby decreasing the likelihood of its decomposition. The active metal sites should possess an appropriate d-band center to balance the relationship between O2 activation and H2O2 desorption. However, current research trends predominantly focus on improving H2O2 generation efficiency, with comparatively less attention directed toward mitigating its decomposition pathways. Platinum (Pt) is a widely employed cocatalyst in catalytic systems and is known for its exceptional oxygen activation capabilities, attributed to its nearly empty dz 2 orbitals [166]. However, the inability of zerovalent Pt(0) to desorption H2O2 effectively usually results in decomposition of H2O2 [167]. Liu et al. [168] deposited three different valence states of Pt into a boron-containing metal organic framework (UiO-67-B) and investigated their effects on the decomposition of H2O2. Their experimental and computational analyses revealed that UiO-67-B/Pt(II) achieved superior catalytic performance through a reduced H2O2 desorption energy barrier (Figs. 8(l) and (m)). This electronic configuration facilitates timely product release from the active sites, thereby effectively inhibiting decomposition pathways and promoting product accumulation. 4 Increased selectivity of H2O2 generation 4.1 One-step two-electron ORR VS. two-step single-electron ORR Thermodynamically, the direct one-step two-electron ORR pathway is more favorable (+0.68 V vs. NHE), whereas kinetically, the two-step single-electron transfer pathway exhibits greater reaction favorability [169]. The two-step single-electron pathway generates reactive oxygen species with strong oxidizing power, which may compromise catalyst stability through oxidative degradation [170,171]. Currently, there are not sufficient studies to establish definitive superiority between the two-and one-step 2e– processes. Understanding the structure-activity relationships between the selectivity of the two pathways and the electronic or macroscopic structure of the catalyst is essential for the targeted design of catalytic materials. Chen et al. [172] constructed a heterojunction photocatalyst (MIL-125-PDI) by combining a perylenetetracarboxylic diimide (PDI) semiconductor with a titanium-based MOF (MIL-125- NH2). The π–π stacking structure of PDI enhanced electron delocalization within the composite system. While pristine MIL-125-NH2 only reduces O2 via a two-step one-electron process, MIL-125-PDI adds a direct one-step two-electron reduction route. This modification increased the H2O2 yield to 4.3 times that of the original MIL-125-NH2 (Figs. 9(a) and (b)). In electrocatalytic applications, Cu has emerged as a promising cocatalyst for improve the selectivity of the 2e– ORR [81,173]. Pristine carbon nitride (CN) undergoes a two-step one-electron ORR pathway [174,175]. In contrast, the Cu-NG/CN nanocomposite, where single Cu atoms were uniformly dispersed on N-doped graphene, inhibited the two-step one-electron reduction pathway and synthesized H2O2 via a one-step two-electron pathway (Figs. 9(c) and (d)) [96]. Potassium doping is an effective strategy for modulating the electronic structure of CN. Huang’s team synthesized K-doped amorphous CN (K-ACN) using plasma treatment [176]. Notably, the open-circuit potential (OCP) of K-ACN increases upon light illumination, indicating efficient accumulation of photogenerated electrons in shallow trap states and the suppression of charge carrier recombination [177]. This contrasts sharply with ACN, where photoelectrons are trapped in deep states, leading to OCP decay due to loss of electrons (Fig. 9(e)). The derivative analysis of the Mott-Schottky plots of ACN shows apparent broad peaks in the –0.4 to 0.2 V potential range, demonstrating that K-ACN possesses passivated trap states (Fig. 9(f)). The photogenerated electrons are transported via thermally activated hopping, which are relatively localized in shallow trap states. Consequently, photoelectrons in the K-ACN conduction band are energetically favorable for the generation of •O2 – and H2O2 via a two-step one-electron ORR pathway (Fig. 9(g)). 4.2 4e– ORR vs. 2e– ORR The competition between the 4e– and 2e– ORR pathways is the primary factor affecting the yield and selectivity of H2O2 [66], and it strongly depends on the type of O2 adsorbed on the metal catalysts [178]. O2 adsorption modes on metal surfaces are broadly categorized into end-on adsorption (Pauling mode) and side-on adsorption (Griffiths mode and Yeager mode), as illustrated in Fig. 10 [179–182]. In the Pauling model, O2 interacts with a single metal site via one oxygen atom, which is not conducive to O–O bond breaking and inhibits the 4e– ORR pathway [183]. However, in Griffiths and Yeager modes, O2 is adsorbed parallel to the metal surface, enabling simultaneous interaction of both oxygen atoms with adjacent metal sites. The 2p orbital of O2 strongly interacts with the d orbital of the metal atom, weakening the O–O bond and promoting the 4e– ORR pathway [184]. The ORR pathways on metallic catalysts are influenced by the O2 adsorption configurations. On metal particles, both end- and side-on adsorption of O2 molecules occurs, making it difficult to prevent O–O bond cleavage on the surfaces of metal particles [185]. However, the majority of metal single-atom sites catalyze reactions via end-on adsorption of O2, which is conducive to the selective 2e– ORR process [186,187]. The specific adsorption mode is determined by the metal d-orbitals and surrounding ligand structure. Shook et al. designed a monomeric Mn complex with an N4O coordination structure. In this system, O2 is adsorbed on the Mn site in the Griffiths mode and is subsequently reduced to H2O [188]. Balancing the catalyst-oxygen interaction is critical to the selectivity of the 2e– ORR; excessive binding may induce O–O bond cleavage, whereas insufficient interaction elevates the reaction energy barrier. Regulating the oxygen binding energy at metal sites is an effective strategy to prevent •OOH fragmentation [189]. Because •OOH is a common intermediate in both the 2e– ORR and 4e– ORR, the interaction of the catalyst with •OOH also determines the product type. Appropriate adjustment of coordination atoms and coordination environments can optimize the adsorption state of oxygen-containing intermediates and improve the activity and selectivity of the 2e– ORR [190]. Liang [191] proposed the synthesis of NiCN-4 (NiCl2·6H2O, 40 mg) by coordinating single nickel atoms with pyridine-like N groups in CN. The ideal coordination environment at the end of O2 adsorption promotes the 2e– ORR process. A comparison of the energy barriers for the 2e– and 4e– ORR on NiCN-4 reveals a stronger selectivity for the 2e– ORR (Figs. 11(a) –(c)). Zhi et al. [192] synthesized two two-dimensional piperazine-linked CoPc-based COFs (CoPc-BTM-COF and CoPcDAB-COF) via nucleophilic substitution reaction with 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTM) and 3,3’-diaminobenzidine (DAB) (Fig. 11(d)). The Gibbs free energy difference (ΔG) was calculated for the ORR processes on the Co sites. The barrier for converting •OOH to H2O2 is lower than that for conversion to •O, indicating that CoPc is more selective for the 2e– ORR (Fig. 11(e)). Zhao et al. [193] investigated one-dimensional coordination polymers (1D CPs) with Co-S2N2 and Ni-S2N2 sites and found that Co-S2N2 exhibits higher selectivity for oxygen reduction in the 4e– ORR pathway, while Ni-S2N2 shows better selectivity for generating H2O2. Zhang et al. [194] investigated SACs possessing well-defined coordination environments and found that Ni-DAR (4,6-diaminoresorcinoln dihydrochloride) with a Ni-N2O2 structure accelerated reaction dynamics by lowering the energy barrier for •OOH formation and enhancing selectivity toward the 2e– ORR process. In NTU-9 with MLCD defects, electrons are concentrated on the nondefective Ti-O cluster, which facilitates the adsorption of both O2 and H+ (Fig. 11(f)) [110]. This electron distribution enhances the interaction with adsorbed O2 and promotes the transfer of electrons to the antibonding π* orbital of O2, thereby driving the consecutive two-step single-electron pathway [195]. This mechanism is crucial for the selective production of H2O2 via the 2e– ORR. In contrast, O2 exhibited a stronger adsorption energy (–2.76 eV) on defective Ti-O clusters, resulting in unstable elongation of the O–O bond. This instability promotes the formation of •OOH and its subsequent reduction to H2O through the 4e– ORR process, thereby reducing the selectivity of the 2e– ORR pathway. These findings highlight the importance of controlling adsorption strength and electron distribution in the design of catalysts for efficient H2O2 production. 4.3 Proton-coupled electron transfer process In the ORR, proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) not only determines the ORR rate but also the selectivity of the reduction products [196,197]. In particular, the rate of proton transfer in the catalytic system significantly influenced the ORR products. When the proton transfer rates were low, •O2 – was generated. When the proton transfer rate was high, the formation of H2O2 was favored. When proton transfer rates are similar to O–O breaking rates, H2O is the main product [198]. However, the diffusion coefficient of protons in water is relatively low [199]. Therefore, the surface of the photocatalyst typically presents a proton-poor microenvironment, resulting in poor selectivity for H2O2 production via the ORR process. The supply of sufficient and efficiently adsorbed protons on the catalyst surface is crucial for improving H2O2 production performance. Li et al. [200] prepared boron doping MOF (UiO-66-B), where π-electrons on the benzene ring are gathered on boron and readily transferred to adsorbed O2 molecules, compared with UiO-66. In UiO-66-B, H+ is adsorbed on the oxygen atom of the Zr–O bond, with a more negative adsorption energy, indicating enhanced H+ enrichment. The adsorption sites of O2 and H+ in UIO-66-B were closer than those in pristine UiO-66, which facilitated PCET and enabled H2O2 production through a two-step electron reduction process (Figs. 12(a) and (b)). Methoxy (–OMe) was incorporated into the MOF UIO-66-NH2, which partially replaced formate (–COO–) at the Zr-oxo nodes [201]. The-OMe-functionalized UIO-66-NH2 introduced more coordination-unsaturated defects, resulting in lattice distortion along the (111) planes (Fig. 12(c)). In the optimized transition state (TS), O…H distance between •OOH and-NH3 + was shorter than that between •OOH and-COO–. The source of •OOH protonation changed from –COOH to –NH3 +, and the protonation path became easier (Fig. 12(d), (e)), resulting in a lower energy barrier from –OOH to TS and higher 2e– ORR selectivity (Fig. 12(f)). 4.4 WOR process The 2e– WOR process is an ideal strategy for synthesizing H2O2. However, owing to uphill thermodynamics, the photocatalytic 2e– WOR process is difficult to achieve. Additionally, the easy decomposition of H2O2 at a high oxidative potential limits the kinetics of overall photocatalytic H2O2 production [202]. Appropriate tuning of the metal coordination environment and electronic structure is crucial for achieving dual-channel H2O2 production. For instance, Lan et al. [203] designed a Co(II)-based metal-organic cage, Co14(L-CH3)24, where the metallic Co sites synergistically cooperated with non-metallic imidazole ligands to catalyze the production of H2O2 through the 2e– ORR and 2e– WOR pathways (Fig. 13(a) ). In the same year, they also reported {Fe-Pt} Hofmann clathrates. Notably, when the spin state of Fe(II) was high-spin (HS), only photocatalytic ORR occurred (Fig. 13(b)). However, when Fe(II) adopted the low-spin (LS) state, H2O2 production proceeded simultaneously through both ORR and WOR pathways at the Pt(II) sites [204]. Tan et al. [205] synthesized carbon nitride nanotubes with interlaminar Al-N3 bridge sites (CNNT-Al) (Figs. 13(c) and (d)). 3s and 3p orbitals of Al hybridized with the 2p orbitals of pyridinic N atoms, inducing interlaminar charge transfer. Additionally, the Al-N3 bridge sites activate adjacent pyridinic N atoms in outer CN layers, thereby promoting the 2e– WOR pathway. O2 serves a dual role as both a reactant in the ORR and a WOR product of the WOR. If the in-situ-generated O2 from the 4e– WOR can participate in the 2e– ORR process, this provides a promising strategy for overcoming the bottleneck in photocatalyzed H2O2 synthesis [206]. Ohno et al. [207] synthesized a single-atom Sb photocatalyst with an electron configuration of 4d 105s 2, which was used for the non-sacrificial photocatalytic synthesis of H2O2 under visible-light irradiation. Unlike other photocatalytic reactions, ORR and WOR operate as mutually promoting half-reactions. Single-atom Sb sites accumulate electrons as reduction sites for O2 (Fig. 13(e)), whereas adjacent N atoms accumulate high-density holes that serve as oxidation sites for the 4e– WOR in photocatalysis, thus providing O2 for the ORR process (Fig. 14(a) ). Chu et al. [208] introduced a method for co-loading oxidation and reduction cocatalysts onto C3N4, where cobalt atoms were coordinated above the void center to enable the 4e– WOR. Anthraquinone molecules were anchored at the edges of the C3N4 nanosheets to enhance 2e– ORR selectivity, thereby achieving spatial separation (Fig. 14(b)). Au-Co-TCPP was synthesized using a 1-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC)/N-hydroxy succinimide (NHS) crosslinking strategy by adsorbing glutathione (GSH) Au nano-compounds with tetrakis-(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin cobalt (Co-TCPP) (Fig. 14(c)) [83]. Photogenerated electrons were transferred from the Au NCs to the Co-TCPP molecules and subsequently to the Co atoms, facilitating the production of H2O2 through the 2e– ORR pathway. In addition, the photogenerated h+ oxidizes H2O to generate O2, providing additional O2 molecules for the ORR process (Fig. 14(d)). 5 Utilization of sacrificial reagent The addition of hole scavengers is a well-established approach to enhance the photosynthetic efficiency of H2O2. These agents capture photogenerated holes, effectively reducing the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and providing additional electrons for the ORR process [209]. This strategy not only improves overall efficiency but also protects the catalyst from oxidative degradation caused by excessive hole-induced reactions [210]. The common sacrificial agents used in these processes include methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), isopropanol (IPA), furfuryl alcohol (FAL), and benzyl alcohol (BA), as summarized in Table 1 . In these processes, O2 is reduced by electrons, while alcohols are oxidized into aldehydes or acids (RCH2OH + 2h+ → RCHO + 2H+). Recent studies have demonstrated significant improvements in H2O2 production by using sacrificial agents. Chen et al. [211] reported crystalline s-heptazine-based COFs (HEP-TAPT-COFs) that achieved an AQY of 15.35% using MeOH as the sacrificial agent. Zhang [212] synthesized carbon nitride (HTCN) that demonstrated excellent photocatalytic performance using IPA as the sacrificial agent. Li’s work on VIA group elements (O, S, Se)-bridged 1D COFs (EO-COF) achieved a H2O2 photosynthetic efficiency of 2675 μmol g–1 h–1 when ethanol was used as the sacrificial agent [213]. Similarly, an asymmetric Zn-N3 active site was formed by bridging the ZIF-8-derived N-doped carbon layer with the C3N4 nanosheets (Figs. 15(a) –(c)) [133]. The oxidation of EtOH on electron-deficient Zn sites triggered rapid carrier transfer, achieving photocatalytic H2O2 production at the molar level. Feng et al. [214] integrated photosensitizers into metal-organic frameworks to construct a catalyst with Ru-Cu dual-functional units (Fig. 15(d)). The yield in ethanol exhibited an enhancement of an order of magnitude. These findings highlight the importance of selecting appropriate sacrificial agents to optimize photocatalytic production of H2O2. The organic phase BA acts as a hole scavenger, allowing the H2O2 or •O2 – produced by the catalyst in the organic phase to separate into water, while the catalysts and oxidation products remain in the organic phase [215,216]. This approach addresses the problem of H2O2 decomposition and reduces the cost of H2O2 extraction. Recently, it was demonstrated that the construction of a water/BA two-phase system prevented the decomposition of H2O2 and simultaneously enabled the production of the value-added product, benzaldehyde. Yamashita et al. [217] grafted MIL-125-NH2 onto different alkyl chains to synthesize hydrophobic MOFs selectively dispersed in BA. The resulting •O2 – was disproportionated in water to produce H2O2, and by decreasing the amount of water, a high concentration of H2O2 was obtained (Fig. 15(e)). Chen [218] synthesized a hydrophobic Ti-doped Zr-based MOF (OPA/Zr100–x Ti x -MOF), and the spatial separation of the MOF and H2O2 in the two-phase system prevented the over-reduction of H2O2 and led to higher activity. Li [219] synthesized a Zn3In2S6/PCN-222 (ZIS/PCN) heterojunction photocatalyst. Hydrophobic ZIS/PCN can be selectively dispersed in the organic phase, whereas the generated H2O2 resides in the aqueous phase, enabling high-concentration H2O2 collection (Fig. 16(a) ). However, sacrificial agents (especially IPA and BA) can be oxidized to form organic peroxides. BA also produces significant amounts of H2O2 by promoting photocatalytic oxidation [220]. Therefore, control groups should be included when using these sacrificial agents to avoid conflicting results. Sacrificial agents inevitably increase the cost of H2O2 isolation as well as the formation of difficult byproducts. An increasing number of studies have begun to favor the construction of catalytic systems in pure water or seawater [221–223]. Another study synthesized ZIF-8/C3N4 composites as efficient photocatalysts for the generation of H2O2 under visible light without the addition of any sacrificial agent, using WOR and ORR processes that promote each other (Fig. 16(b)) [224]. Ni et al. [225] designed COF-2CN, which exhibited highly efficient photocatalytic generation of H2O2 in a wide pH range of water and real water sources. Teng et al. [226] constructed a Bi3TiNbO9@C4N heterojunction by coating C4N on Bi3TiNbO9, achieving a remarkable H2O2 production rate of 1.25 mmol g–1 h–1 without using sacrificial agents (Fig. 16(c)). 6 Summary and perspectives 6.1 Summary Photocatalysis is a highly promising new technology for producing H2O2. Despite extensive efforts by researchers to enhance catalytic efficiency through various strategies, various organic photocatalysts still face significant challenges. These include narrow light absorption ranges, high photogenerated carrier recombination rates, insufficient H2O2 generation activity and selectivity, and poor product stability, all of which severely limit the optimum performance of these catalysts. To address these issues, researchers have introduced metal co-catalysts doped into organic carriers. These metal co-catalysts serve as electron sinks and electron transfer bridges, thereby enhancing carrier separation efficiency. Additionally, the metal atoms functioned as active sites for oxygen adsorption and activation, further boosting the photocatalytic performance of the system. This review summarizes recent advances in metal-based organic photocatalysts for photosynthesis of H2O2 from the perspective of electronic structure modulation. It covers the mechanism of photocatalytic ORR and WOR, improvement of the catalyst light absorption range and photogenerated carrier separation efficiency, optimization of O2 adsorption and activation processes, and enhancement of photosynthesis H2O2 selectivity. Additionally, the types of sacrificial agents used in catalytic systems, their roles, and limitations are discussed. With the application of catalysts such as metal-organic frameworks, metal covalent organic frameworks, metal-doped C3N4, and supramolecular metal-organic cages for the photocatalytic production of H2O2, research on metal-based organic catalysts has made significant progress. However, the use of photocatalysis for solar energy still falls short of expectations, and substantial challenges remain in practical industrial production. 6.2 Challenges and future perspectives 6.2.1 Agglomeration of metal atoms Metal atoms tend to agglomerate during high-temperature carbonation, resulting in a low loading of metal atom sites. Currently, only a few metal-based organic catalysts reflect quantitative loading of metal sites. The lack of direct synthesis methods using oriented coordination strategies severely hampers the study of catalyst structure-activity relationships. Further efforts should focus on designing organic ligands with strong coordinating groups (N, S, and O) to form stable coordination bonds with metals and maintain dispersed states during the carbonation process. Additionally, quantitative analysis of metal sites can be conducted by combining inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and XPS. 6.2.2 Instability of metal based organic catalysts Instability is a critical issue that can lead to catalyst degradation and loss of catalytic activity over time. This challenge may be addressed by designing catalysts with stable coordination or dynamic coordinating groups. 6.2.3 Limited electronic structure modulation Single-atom catalysts typically feature a single-metal-atom coordination environment, with most studies focusing on M–N coordination. This limits the in-depth exploration of electronic structure modulation and its effect on performance. Therefore, the introduction of metal coordination atoms such as O, S, and P, or even coordinated halogens or hydroxyl groups, represents a promising strategy to enhance catalyst design. 6.2.4 Coexistence of reactive oxygen species Although multiple reactive oxygen species coexist during H2O2 production, this complexity has not been adequately addressed in existing studies. Therefore, additional testing techniques such as such as in situ Raman Spectroscopy, in situ infrared spectroscopy, and mass spectrometry should be employed to clarify the reaction course and mechanism of various radicals during a reaction. 6.2.5 Balancing activity and selectivity The adsorption capacity of O2 at the catalytic site determines catalytic activity; however, strong adsorption can cause further decomposition of •OOH. Balancing high catalytic activity and selectivity remains a challenging issue. Therefore, greater emphasis should be placed on tuning the electronic structure of catalysts and studying metal spin states to facilitate targeted control over adsorption energies of intermediates. Photocatalytic ORR and WOR for the preparation of high-value H2O2 are promising research avenues. It is anticipated that research on metal-based organic semiconductors in photocatalysis will become increasingly diverse and that these technologies will be widely used in practical production in the near future. Shaonan Gu (School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Qilu University of Technology) received his Ph.D degree in 2016 from the University of Science and Technology Beijing. He then conducted postdoctoral research at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology and the Hong Kong Polytechnic University from 2016 to 2018, respectively. His research interests center on designing and synthesizing photocatalysts with activities for photocatalytic hydrogen peroxide production and photocatalytic water splitting, as well as developing and investigating energy conversion and storage materials such as lithium ions and lithium sulfur battery electrodes, including their structural properties through theoretical calculations. His recent progresses focused on the theory and application of materials like MOFs, rare earth single atoms, and COFs in photo- and electro-catalysis. Now he has published over 80 peer-reviewed papers. Guowei Zhou (School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Qilu University of Technology) received his B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees in Chemistry at Shandong University (1986, 1989, and 2001). He carried out postdoctoral research in Prof. Young Soo Kang’s group at Pukyong National University (Korea) from 2012 to 2013 and worked as an advanced research scholar in Prof. Shihe Yang’s group at The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology from 2015 to 2016. He is currently a Professor at Qilu University of Technology. His research group focuses primarily on the design, controlled synthesis, modification, and hierarchical assembly mesostructure functional materials with specific morphology for energy applications including batteries and photocatalysis. His current research interests include the different application of functional mesoporous materials for photocatalytic hydrogen production, CO2 reduction, environmental remediation, and energy conversion and storage. He has published more than 160 peer-reviewed papers. He was granted 54 national invention patents in China. He also serves as the editor for Acta Phys.-Chim. Sin. from 2025.

coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) has emerged as a promising approach because of its simplicity and environmental benefits. However, significant challenges remain obstacles to their advancement, such as the rapid recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and sluggish surface redox reactions on nonmetallic organic catalysts. Metal-based organic catalysts with tunable electronic structures are considered ideal for exploring the mechanisms and structure-performance relationships in H2O2 synthesis. This review summarizes the fundamental principles of photocatalytic H2O2 synthesis via oxygen reduction and water oxidation reactions. Recent advancements in electronic structure tuning strategies for metal-based organic catalysts are critically examined, focusing on their impact on light absorption range, photogenerated carrier separation, O2 activation, and the selective generation of H2O2. In addition, this review comprehensively evaluates the applications of sacrificial agents in photocatalytic reaction systems and offers insights into the future development of metal-based organic catalysts for H2O2 photosynthesis.
